PURPOSE
The purpose of this policy is to establish requirements for cyber risk assessment of PeaceHealth information systems to aid in protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of PeaceHealth's information systems.
DEFINITIONS
•
Caregiver: PeaceHealth employee, volunteer, trainee, and other persons whose conduct, in the performance of work for PeaceHealth, is under the direct control of PeaceHealth, regardless of whether they are paid by PeaceHealth.
•
Confidential Information: Information related to patients, caregivers, providers, financial data, and /or any other information pertaining to PeaceHealth business or proprietary information is to be considered strictly confidential unless specified otherwise.
•
Information System: A discrete set of information resources organized for the collection, processing, maintenance, use, sharing, dissemination, or disposition of information (FIPS 200).
POLICY
It is the policy of PeaceHealth that the following requirements are implemented to support cyber risk assessment of PeaceHealth information systems:
1. Categorization of Information Systems:
a.
PeaceHealth categorizes information and the information system as described in the PeaceHealth Data Protection Procedure.
i.
PeaceHealth documents the security categorization of information systems in the Configuration Management Database (CMDB) in accordance with the PeaceHealth Data Protection Policy.
ii.
PeaceHealth ensures that the security categorization decisions of information systems are reviewed and approved by Information Security and Technology Solution Partners (TSP) leadership or their designees.
2. Cyber Risk Assessment:
a.
PeaceHealth assesses the risk of the unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction of the information system and the information it processes, stores, or transmits.
b.
PeaceHealth documents cyber risk assessment results and protects them from unauthorized access.
c.
PeaceHealth reviews cyber risk assessment results on a regular basis as part of a continuous cyber risk management process.
d.
PeaceHealth disseminates cyber risk assessment results to key personnel who are involved in risk response decision-making.
e.
PeaceHealth updates the cyber risk assessment annually, at a minimum, or whenever there are significant changes to the information system or environment of operation (including the identification of new threats and vulnerabilities) or other conditions that may impact the security state of the system.
3. Vulnerability Scanning:
a.
PeaceHealth scans for vulnerabilities in the information system and hosted applications as specified in the Continuous Vulnerability Management Standards Policy.
b.
PeaceHealth employs vulnerability scanning tools and techniques that facilitate interoperability among tools and automate parts of the vulnerability management process by using standards for the following:
i.
Enumerating platforms, software flaws, and improper configurations;
ii.
Formatting checklists and test procedures; and
iii.
Measuring vulnerability impact.
c.
PeaceHealth analyzes vulnerability scan reports and results from information security control assessments.
d.
PeaceHealth remediates legitimate vulnerabilities in accordance with the Continuous Vulnerability Management Standards Policy.
e.
PeaceHealth shares information obtained from the vulnerability scanning process and information security control assessments in accordance with the Continuous Vulnerability Management Standards Policy to help eliminate similar vulnerabilities in other information systems (i.e., systemic weaknesses or deficiencies).
COMPLIANCE
Individuals included in the scope of this policy are required to comply with the policy and all associated policies, standards, and procedures. Violations are subject to removal of access and/or corrective action, up to and including termination of employment or other business relationship with PeaceHealth. Any deviations from security standards observed in the production environment must be communicated to the Information Security department immediately upon discovery. If an exception to this policy is necessary, it must be submitted in accordance with the Information Security Policy and Standards Exceptions policy.
